data.title: List::move_before updates front/back pointers, fixes #2255
data.body: The move_before function wasn't updating the list's front/back pointers if the element to be moved was the front or the back of the list. Fixes issue #2255

data.title: List::move_before bug
data.body: `List::move_before(Element* value, Element* where)` breaks the list when `value` is the front or the back of the list, because the list's front/back pointer is not updated and continues to point to `value` after the move. I'll submit a pull request with a fix.

data.title: Godot have problem with some characters in Windows username while exporting
data.body: My Windows username is "Rafał". While exporting to Android Godot can't find template APK, but I can find this file in filesystem. Godot don't see "ł" character

data.title: Enable jarsigner from openjdk 1.7 support
data.body:
I use the following script to use jarsigner from openjdk 1.7

``` shell
rm -f simple-rpg.apk simple-rpg-unaligned.apk simple-rpg-unsigned2.zip simple-rpg-unsigned2.apk
rm -Rf simple-rpg-unsigned
unzip -d simple-rpg-unsigned simple-rpg-unsigned.apk
cd simple-rpg-unsigned
rm -Rf META-INF
zip -r ../simple-rpg-unsigned2.zip *
cd ..
mv simple-rpg-unsigned2.zip simple-rpg-unsigned2.apk

jarsigner -verbose -digestalg SHA1 -sigalg MD5withRSA -keystore ~/android/release.keystore -signedjar simple-rpg-unaligned.apk simple-rpg-unsigned2.apk slapin
/home/slapin/android-sdk-linux/tools/zipalign -v 4 simple-rpg-unaligned.apk simple-rpg.apk
```

Most problems are because Godot doesn't remove signing files in templates
if these are there. You can just drop whole META-INF. Also it is easy to find on the Internet,
that jarsigner from jdk 1.7 requires the following options to work with android:
-digestalg SHA1 -sigalg MD5withRSA
digestalg also might be set to MD5.

data.title: Godot animations are extremely hard to use
data.body:
- [ ] AnimationTreePlayer Filter mechanism is counter-intuitive and buggy for Blend nodes.
  It is very hard to find the intended track as bone hierarchy doesn't really work there and
  very hard to figure-out what filters actually do.
- [X] AnimationTreePlayer totally fail with non-looping animations (it can play them only once, then
  only last frame is played)
- [ ] Importer imports non-deform bones even if told not to, which adds hundreds of unneeded tracks
  on complex rigs
- [ ] AnimationTreePlayer is very hard to use with animation count > 20, as it is not possible to group
  nodes, hide/show nodes, etc. It is very hard to visually find needed animations.

data.title: Autocompletion Service Support for external text editors
data.body:
Allow for external editor to connect to a specific port for GDScript code completion.
for instance, when the editor is on an editor plugin could send a request in the form of:
http://localhost:9999/auto_complete?postions=position with the buffer as the post buffer.
In return get a json list of available completions from the internal analyzer.
This will allow the use of external editors without having to explicitly support them.

It could even be implemented in a simpler manner with sockets and a bi-directional json steam

data.title: ConfigFile.get_value() should accept default_value as 3rd parameter
data.body:
ConfigFile.get_value() should have a 3rd parameter which will be returned if the section & key does not exist.

Suggested edit:

```
void get_value( String section, String key, var default_value=null ) const
```

For example:

```
var cf = ConfigFile.new()
cf.load("user://configs.cfg")
var user_id = cf.get_value("user", "id", -1)
# if user/id does not exist, user_id = -1
# else user_id = whatever value is saved
```

data.title: audio sample import bugs
data.body:
Several things are going wrong with importing audio samples.  I've got a sample imported already, but when I change the wav file that it depended on, I don't see the refesh checkbox on the top right do anything.  When I click reimport, it's not in the list.

When I reimport it myself manually, it does overwrite the sample.  The loop flag doesn't work though.  If I edit the sample, I see that the loop parameters (forward, length...) were retained from the previous version of the sample, but they don't work.  I save and reopen the project, and the loop paramters are gone.  It seems the reimport doesn't set the loop parameters (even though the box is checked), and it also doesn't refresh the loop parameters in the GUI to show that they're reset.

data.title: GDScript atan2() and Vector.atan2() bug
data.body:
I believe the Vector.atan2() function does not work as intended. Here is an example script that displays atan2 values for various unit vectors (anti-clockwise / trigonometric order) and expected values :

``` python
printt("Vector", "atan2 value", "expected value") 
printt(Vector2(1,0), Vector2(1,0).atan2(), 0)
printt(Vector2(1,1), Vector2(1,1).atan2(), PI/4)
printt(Vector2(0,1), Vector2(0,1).atan2(), PI/2)
printt(Vector2(-1,1), Vector2(-1,1).atan2(), 3*PI/4)
printt(Vector2(-1,0), Vector2(-1,0).atan2(), PI)
printt(Vector2(-1,-1), Vector2(-1,-1).atan2(), -3*PI/4)
printt(Vector2(0,-1), Vector2(0,-1).atan2(), -PI/2)
printt(Vector2(1,-1), Vector2(1,-1).atan2(), -PI/4)
```

Output : 

``` python
Vector  atan2 value expected value
1,0     1.570796    0
1,1     0.785398    0.785398
0,1     0           1.570796
-1,1    -0.785398   2.356194
-1,0    -1.570796   3.141593
-1,-1   -2.356194   -2.356194
0,-1    3.141593    -1.570796
1,-1    2.356194    -0.785398
```

Obviously, atan2() method calculates value for the inverse vector (0,1) instead of (1,0), (-1,1) instead of (1,-1), and so one.

data.title: Saving a scene apparently shows a major speed regression
data.body:
_Bugsquad edit:_ Seen in Godot 1.2 June 29 dev. build

Confirmed on a Win64 dev. build done using MingW 64bit on the 29th of June.

It seems to me that saving scenes in the latest available builds of Godot version 1.2 is a lot slower than the equivalent function in Godot 1.1. Complex scenes can take nearly ten seconds to save compared to saving almost instantly in the official release. The good news is that there's no crashing and no instances of Godot saving over the wrong data (even with multiple scene editing in play).

System; Win7 64 bit with an ATI 7xxx GPU

Anyway, it would be nice to know if this can be solvable.

data.title: Import/Re-import 3D scene does not show new changes
data.body:
_Bugsquad edit:_ Seen in Godot 1.2 June 29 dev. build

Confirmed on a Win64 dev. build done using MingW 64bit on the 29th of June.

To reproduce, open an established 3D scene and try to import a new version of it (or re-import). It will appear as if the importer has done nothing as you will still find the scene and the node tree looking exactly the same.

However, going back to Godot 1.1 official and opening the scene there shows the updated geometry and node tree just fine, which might make sense since the dev. build showed no errors in the console relating to the actual importing.

System; Win7 64 bit with an ATI 7xxx GPU/

data.title: If window resize is disabled it prevents both users AND code from modifying the size.
data.body:
If "OS.is_window_resizable()" is false (due in my case to the project settings), the user shouldn't be able to resize the window while the program is running. Which does happen.
However... it also prevents that resizability in code! For instance...

newframesize = (640,480)
OS.set_window_resizable(true)
OS.set_window_size(newframesize)

This will work!... but then the user can resize the window even if I only wanted that one size!
So we try this right after...

OS.set_window_resizable(false)

And it sadly resets the window size back to the project default! Just setting the window size alone does nothing because the resizability settings prevent it.

My use case is a setup screen that resizes when you go into the input setup submenu. I might even have it just be another scene in the entire game if I can resize the window proper & on-the-fly. Thanks in advance for any fix to this issue because it's a bit of a showstopper. I'd have to make them all separate projects or reorganize the menus if not!

data.title: 'printraw' prints nothing
data.body:
print("1")
printraw("2")
printraw("3")

This code should produce the following result:
1
23

However it produces this result instead:
1

[...]

I wish to have this option better organize through spacing the readability of my error and feedback messages. Thanks in advance for any fix.

data.title: captured mouse doesn't return on break
data.body: With mouse mode set to capture in X11, hitting a breakpoint or error should make the cursor available again.  Currently, the cursor is still hidden, so using the debugger (or, in fact, anything else on the computer) with the mouse is not possible.  Alt tabbing and killing the editor returns the cursor to normal.

data.title: Shape offset on tileset
data.body:
![pantallazo-ventana sin titulo](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6296184/8503195/c6c3b3f0-2191-11e5-8e47-ee9a0999bcde.png)

When using several shapes on a single tile, a single shape-offset is used for the tile. It would be cool to have a per-shape offset for the tiles.

Also when using an offset for the texture, the collision shape does not use the on-editor shape offset. Instead it uses half the size of the texture as the offset. I think the collision shape and the texture should have different offsets.

Notice that this is currently fixed by manually editing the tileset shape-offset parameter, but this change is overwritten every time the tileset is exported.
When exporting the tileset insted of using the shape offset within the sprite node (32, 32), it uses half the size of the texture (32, 40).

This is what happens on my game:
![pantallazo-ventana sin titulo-2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6296184/8503329/0f839586-2194-11e5-9318-d8ce199a1775.png)

data.title: RegEx does not detect end of line anchor
data.body:
On 1.1stable Windows, the following code:

```
var test = RegEx.new()
test.compile("\\w+$")
print(test.find("hello"))
print(test.find(" hello"))
print(test.find("hello!"))
print(test.find("hello world!"))
test.compile("^\\w+")
print(test.find("hello"))
print(test.find(" hello"))
print(test.find("hello!"))
print(test.find("hello world!"))
```

should match the first two lines but instead produces this output:

```
-1 <-- Should be 0
-1 <-- Should be 1
-1
-1
0
-1
0
0
```

data.title: Allow specifying mandatory points for certain routes
data.body:
For Navigation2D and Navigation, there should be a feature that allows the caller of `get_simple_path` to specify possible mandatory points to follow the player. For instance,
![navigation_mandatory_points](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/673620/8490776/8b544dce-20e3-11e5-8f42-f31d19f05330.png)

The pink dot is the player. The red dot is an enemy. The current navigation classes would probably give path 0 as the best option for the enemy, which might not be possible if the enemy cannot jump that high. So instead, depending on the jumping capabilities of an enemy, a list of possible points*, representing the best places the enemy can follow to reach their target can be fed into `get_simple_path`.

*in this case, the best possible jump position to get to the second platform and some point on the second platform
